definition[0]: to control the direction a vehicle is going, for example by turning a wheel
example[0]: He was steering with only one hand.
definition[1]: to guide someone’s behaviour or the way a situation develops
example[2]: Helen tried to steer the conversation away from herself.
example[3]: Teachers try to steer pupils away from drugs.
note[1]: steer somebody towards/away from/through etc something
definition[2]: to be in charge of an organization, team etc and make decisions that help it to be successful, especially during a difficult time
example[4]: McKinney steered the company through the recession.
definition[3]: to guide someone to a place, especially while touching them
example[5]: Joel steered Don and Louise towards the backyard.
definition[4]: a young male cow whose sex organs have been removed
definition[5]: to guide the way a situation develops, by influencing people’s ideas or actions
example[6]: He managed to steer his colleagues to a compromise.
example[7]: Farmers must be steered away from high-yield farming, towards more environmentally friendly methods.
definition[6]: to be in charge of an organization, team, or process and make decisions that help it to be successful, especially during a difficult time
example[8]: Rivetti is steering a comprehensive restructuring program that will transform the company.
definition[7]: to avoid something or someone unpleasant or difficult
example[9]: Will the economy steer clear of a recession?
definition[8]: to choose a course of action that is not extreme and that does not favour one side more than another
example[10]: The President will try to steer a middle course between environmentalists and the oil industry.
